awd_titl_txt: Physics with New Molecular Systems: Quantum Interactions, Cooling, and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Atoms are the basic building blocks of nature and their behavior is governed by a microscopic theory of matter called quantum mechanics. Our understanding of nearly everything we see in nature relies on quantum mechanics as applied to atoms and their close cousins, molecules (two or more atoms stuck together by a chemical bond). From humans and other living things to computers and the internet, physical systems can be explained only by knowing how atoms and molecules behave in detail. Yet, although quantum mechanics has been very successful in describing very simple atomic systems, we do not yet know how to apply the theory quantitatively to describe all the phenomena that we see. In particular, to invent new technological and biological substances, we need to understand the quantum mechanics of atoms and molecules better. The eventual goal of much of physics (including atomic physics) is to have a complete understanding of all matter and the tools to invent new types of matter. This project is a step toward developing a detailed quantum understanding of the interactions between atoms and molecules in a gas at a very low temperature. When cooled, the quantum nature of atoms and molecules is greatly amplified, exposing its nature to careful study. 

The essential experimental approach to this work is to use magnetic trapping of atoms and molecules to study their collisions using laser spectroscopy. The technical method will be to use buffer-gas cooling to form a beam of atoms and molecules, which will be optically pumped into magnetically trapped states as they pass through the trapping region. Half the molecules in the beam are originally in the low-field-seeking quantum state. These molecules lose energy as they approach the magnetic field maximum of the trap, where they will be optically pumped into their high-field-seeking state. These molecules then continue to lose energy as they travel toward the trap center. Near the trap center lasers pump the molecules into their trapped state. Only two photons are scattered in this process and this (along with energy loss as the molecules pass through the trap) leads to irreversible trap loading. We will trap molecules of calcium monofluoride and other small molecules into a magnetic trap using this method. Atoms can also be co-loaded with molecules, at high enough density for evaporative cooling. We will co-load lithium and/or potassium atoms and study collisions between them and the trapped molecules, testing molecular theory and investigating a route toward ultracold molecules using sympathetic cooling. Spectroscopy will reveal both the state distribution of the molecules, as well as their number and temperature. Investigation of trap loss can be used to study spin-relaxation collisions (for which there is detailed theory for some atom-molecule pairs). The longer term goal of this work is to enable observation of exchange of energy and other phenomena in increasingly complex atom-molecule collisions, starting with diatomic and triatomic molecules. This will add to our fundamental understanding of nature and help science to design new physical systems and new tools for chemistry and biology.

Award Title: Physics with New Molecular Systems: Quantum Interactions, Cooling, and Applications

      Federal Award ID: 1505961

      Report Submission Period: 09/01/2018 to 08/31/2019

 

This project is aimed at cooling molecules and then studying collisions of polyatomic molecules. Collisions lie at the core of many fundamental phenomena. Having a complete quantum-mechanical picture of the collision of two particles in a specific quantum state is at the heart of quantum chemistry where calculations of collision rates between complex molecules is limited by computational power. Collisions also pave the path for cooling molecules further towards the “ultra-cold” regime. New phases of matter, like Bose-Einstein condensates (BECs) of atoms, have been achieved through evaporation. In this process, hot particles from a trap escape while the remaining particles collide with each other. This leads to thermalization of the remaining particles at lower temperatures and, hence, cooling. A critical step towards a future BEC of molecules is control over collisions between particles and a deeper understanding of collisions between molecules.

            Before the desired collisions can be studied or used, the molecules must be cooled. Thus, the focus of our project was the cooling of polyatomic molecules. We demonstrated one-dimensional Sisyphus cooling of a beam of SrOH, a linear triatomic molecule. In this type of cooling, molecules lose energy as they climb a potential energy “hill” created by a standing wave of light. Whenever the summit is reached, the molecules are forced back to the bottom of the hill only to climb it again. With this technique, we cooled from 50 mK to below 1 mK.

We have also demonstrated a different scheme, the bichromatic force, to efficiently apply force to molecules using laser light. This effect relies on two counter-propagating lasers at different wavelengths. If the lasers are carefully controlled, then the molecule will reliably cycle between a low-energy and high-energy state, and experience momentum “kicks” from the laser beams each time it changes state. We deflected a beam of molecules using the resulting forces and established it as a viable strategy to slow down molecules without needing to excite the molecules as many times as in traditional beam-slowing techniques.

As an immediate extension of our work with SrOH, we did theoretical work to propose an experiment to study the invisible dark matter (“seen” only through its gravitational interaction with regular matter and light) that permeates our solar system. We found that dark matter particles will change the effective masses of protons and electrons to change, causing molecules to vibrate more or less quickly. By carefully studying different kinds of vibrations in polyatomic molecules like SrOH, we found that it is possible to precisely measure small changes in these masses and therefore infer the properties of dark matter.

We did theoretical work analyzing the possibility of using the molecule YbOH to probe signatures of new fundamental high-energy particles. These particles would form a virtual “cloud” around the electrons inside molecules, deforming their apparent shape away from a perfect sphere. By closely studying the behavior of electrons inside molecules containing heavy atoms like ytterbium, it is possible to infer how deformed the shape of the electron is. A trap with large numbers of molecules will enable extremely long (and therefore precise) interrogations of the electron, making it possible to probe the shape of the electron on a scale one thousand times smaller than ever before.

Finally, we theoretically studied more complex species such as “symmetric top” molecules, which can spin around a central axis. Such species could be precisely controlled while remaining relatively immune from disturbances in their environment, making them a promising platform for quantum computation. Additionally, molecules only slightly more complex than YbOH could enable probes of unobserved particles with even longer and more precise measurements of the electron’s shape.

Intellectual Merit: During the entire duration of this project, we have made strides in the direction of cooling and trapping larger polyatomic molecules. Not only is that a frontier of AMO physics, but it also broadens our grasp of fundamental phenomena. With eventual access to quantum chemistry and collisions with single quantum state control, we hope to help design new tools in Chemistry and Biology. Also, by using polyatomic molecules in the search for the electron EDM, we can provide a stringent probe of fundamental physics. Finally, with symmetric top molecular theory, we understand better how to create robust systems for quantum computation and even more favorable platforms for precision measurement.

Broader Impacts: This project led to the training of 2 graduate and 3 undergraduate students. During its course many experimental techniques were developed that are of broader application to the field of AMO physics. This knowledge was disseminated through peer reviewed publications, presentations, and a doctoral thesis. Our work on SrOH was featured in various news outlets and blogs, hence reaching a larger general audience.
